  379. I've had this product for a few months now and have had some very interesting experiences with it. I've read all of the reviews some of which sing praises and others which seem to condemn the product. This is a VERY good product...I mean you can't really get any better than this. In terms of cuts, dings, gashes, etc, it is definitely possible but more so from not paying attention, taking your time and planning what you're going to do (think about it - do you think your barber just hacks away?? Consider his approach...meticulous, deliberate, extended). Have you gotten a little ding from the barber? You should have the same expectations here. However there are a few things to consider early which for me I believe are essential: 1) If you are not accustomed to shaving/trimming and venturing in this area for the first time, then: a) Talk to a woman (someone you trust); they've been doing this for years (think about it) ask for advice for your particular situation b) Make sure you clean up first. That is, take a shower and really clean your self c) Start slow...if you have a lot of hair then put the trimmer to the number one position and start from there then gradually move down to number four d) Once trimmed, leave it there and get accustomed to it and when I say accustomed I mean your skin. Having all that hair gone changes the 'climate' (think about it) e) Once you are accustomed and want to go further (shave)...repeat steps a and b. Use the shaver and follow the directions that came with the manual and advice from your woman friend. 2) If you are accustomed to shaving/trimming then you should appreciate this product for helping to make the process quick(er) and hopefully painless What I like most about this product is the battery life. I charged it 2½ months ago and its still going. I also liked the weight, seemed sturdy (go figure). I also liked the design which in my opinion helped me to 'reach' (at this point let me re-iterate, makesure you clean yourself properly). For the new ones getting into trimming and more so shaving please PLEASE PLEASE: - clean yourself well - go in one direction (for now) - take your time (go in stages) With that said you should have a great experience. Hope this helps.

  390. Unlike other reviewers, who complain about the design of the groomer and the side trimmers of this groomer, in my opinion, it has a perfect design. only if users understand the mechanism of the groomer, they will shave their body without any problem. Keep the groomer horizontal, and slide it forward. There is no need to press. By sliding the groomer, side trimmers will cut the long hairs, and long hairs become short enough to be shaved by a hidden trimmer, which is covered by a thin foil. Otherwise, without the side trimmers, you can not trim long hairs, and before anything else,you have to cut the long hairs with a scissor which is dangerous, and it takes time. As I said before, only keep the groomer in a way that the side trimmers become parallel with the surface of the skin, and slide the groomer forward (or backward). As a result, the weight of the groomer is enough for cutting the long hairs by side trimmers. After that, short hairs will be guided through the foil holes, and the covered main trimmer will shave your body without any problem. I shaved my pubic hair without difficulty.

Also, it could get lost easily.<br /><br />The body shaver side does cut very close to the skin, also without nicking, and has a dual sided fine trimmer as well to knock down the hairs. Also, I find the handle design is good and long, allowing me to reach all sections of my back, with a little stretch. I don't need a second device to reach my back.<br /><br />Of course, you probably figured out by now that this is NOT a face trimmer, so disregard any reviews that knock off points for not shaving your beard well enough.<br /><br />So, insofar as a shaver/trimmer/clipper for body hair, this thing works great!<br /><br />Now for the bad:<br />The charge is terrible. I wish I could use it with a cord, but, it only works cordless. I can hardly trim my entire chest without the charge depleting. I'm not THAT hairy of a guy either. It lasts 10 minutes at the most (from the very first day I used it). I would expect something of this size (it is not small, measuring 7.5\\" long) to last at least 20 minutes like my sideburn/beard trimmer, which is 1/3 the size.<br /><br />And the charging cradle, though it looks nice, is not well balanced, only holds the trimmer when on a flat surface and cannot be mounted on a wall. It needlessly folds, but really doesn't save any space by doing so, and you cannot connect the trimmer to the charger alone, you must use the stand. So, if you travel, that's three things to take (trimmer/charger/stand) because you can't charge it and take it with you, you will not get through but one trimming session at best.<br /><br />For $50 here on Amazon with free shipping, it was cheaper than my local store. But if you want something with a longer charge, or that can be used with the cord when the charge is depleted, look elsewhere.the charge is depleted, look elsewhere.

  410. Now all you need is the foil shaver to finish the stubbles. However, this can't be done because the two moving blades will cut you when you press the shaver close to your skin.   413. I purchased this because of all the great reviews on this site. I have to shave the same area over and over to see any results and even then its not close enough.It is probably effective for someone with light body hair.
  414. First off, this is the BEST body grooming device out there today. If you want to be smooth wherever or just some touching up, this is the gadget for the job. Far less irritation than manual or other electric razors. I've had my Bodygroom since it first launched years ago and have been upgrading as Norelco improves the product. The pivot head is great because it better follows the contours of your body and is especially handy in the groin (be careful down there!). In my experience, shaving wet increases the friction and doesn't allow the blades to cut as close to the skin. If you want a shave that's as close as a manual razor would be, minus the irritation, use baby powder (made of cornstarch, not talc). Sprinkle the powder over the area you're going to shave first, then gently rub it in so the powder covers the whole area evenly. This will create a smooth, dry shaving surface so the blades can cut close but will lessen the risk of nicking the skin. It will also help clean out the hair from the razor head by absorbing any skin oil/moisture and thus the hair can just be blown/brushed out easily for cleanup. Make sure to replace blades roughly every six months or whenever they become dull (you'll notice you have to push harder and sweep over areas more frequently with dull blades, and will tend to get more nicks). Use small, gentle, 1-2\\" strokes for areas of dense hair, and broader strokes for just a light dusting of hair. Do this before you shower so you can hop in under the spray after shaving and rinse off any remaining powder. However, if you're on the go fast you can simply brush a towel gently across the area and that'll get rid of the excess powder, too. Using powder will also reduce friction between your clothes and shaving areas, so this is particularly good for athletic folks or anyone who wears tight clothes.
  415. Works great. Haven't experienced any nicks yet and handle easily.
  416. It really works. I totally recommend. Painless, fast, no redness, can wet and you can use in your entire body (except head). After star using you literally cannot stop! Cons: The plastic parts looks cheap and non durable. There is no case. Kind of big in size. The charger specifications are different from my brand-new Philips razor, so I cannot use the same charger cable in both products. I highly recommend this product!

I'm very happy to report I used it for the first time last night and did NOT have that \\"OH $&%@!!!!!\\" moment of something being pulled, nicked, cut, torn into. I was very cautious around \\"the boys\\" at first but it just really worked well in taming my jungle. A smooth and more importantly PAIN FREE trimming experience. It also did a really nice job on my beard. As other's have noted the beard trimming guard is not the hardest/toughest plastic around. The guard could be described as flimsy, but I'm trimming my beard not opening a can of tuna so I'm not overly concerned about it. The unit itself (the trimmer not mine) feels good and sturdy in your hand and is a good size (ok, mine could be described that way too, lol). Look, as guys we're never going to feel \\"great\\" about having sharp metal objects cutting \\"that area\\". But this excellent trimmer made the process easy, painless, and my life didn't flash before my eyes in terror while using it. It works, buy it.

For years I tried using traditional razors and no matter what shave lotions, gels, creams, etc I always suffered from razor burn and in-grown hairs. With the Bodygroomer I have just smooth skin and no irritation in the nether regions. I have found it works best as a wet shave in the shower using Bump Patrol cool shave gel that I get through StockNGo and I follow with Target's brand of Neutrogena Calming Lotion. I do use a Gillette Fusion on the scrotum area as a personal preference (since I never had any irritation there). Guys, if you like to keep that area looking good (we shouldn't ask women to do anything we would not do ourselves!) this is the PERFECT razor to use. I use the Amazon prescription service and change my blades every six-months and I am not sure if it is necessary but as cheap as it is I feel like it is worth it. Buy it and you won't regret it!!

The level 1 cut is just too long, and if I take the guard off it cuts my beard too short. I understand that is a personal critique, seeing as people obviously grow their beard at different lengths, but my 15$ Norelco beard trimmer would do the job if I wanted to switch back to it.<br /><br />The shaver on the flip side also does the job, but not for what it costs, imho. It's not nick-free and it frequently pinches in places that you don't want it pinching. It doesn't nick as bad as my unguarded Norelco beard trimmer, but I just assume when you shell out 50$ or more for a beard and body trimmer that you don't have to be so overly cautious. Perhaps I'm wrong.<br /><br />This does work great in the shower, however. With that I am well pleased. The charger also works well and the charge itself lasts for a long time.   461. I'm reviewing the most expensive Bodygroom because you really need to understand something before you plunk down this much cash:<br /><br />You can't plug this in to recharge. You plug the charger in, and set the Bodygroom on the cradle. But the BG charger/cradles are cheap. Mine broke before the Bodygroom did. So... read other reviews to confirm this is an uncommon issue. While you're reading, see if other people comment on the battery life. Yes, the batteries are NiMH. And it appears this is a 1-hour charge, vs. cheaper Norelco products that require 8-12 hour charge times. That's usually a good sign.<br /><br />As for the Bodygroom itself... yes, it works. Amazingly well. I'm on my second (cheaper) one. Since the latest cradle fell apart, I'm having to do some wacky workarounds to recharge.<br /><br />Heed the warnings and do NOT use this to trim extremely tough beard hairs. That's what Norelco triple-head razors are for.

Both heads detach to clean out any hair that might have gotten stuck. The battery life is more then sufficient for an entire body use (~35mins fully charged). All in all this is exactly what I needed in the most convenient and effective design. I've had mine for 2months now and assuming it doesn't crap out on me I can't find a single flaw.

Even though I never re-charged until the red light came on, and did a complete discharge/recharge from time-to-time, after a couple of years, my first unit would require as much as 5-6 hours of charging time to yield maybe 10 minutes of usage. Having to replace this rather expensive shaver every couple of years makes it an expensive proposition, too. But, like I said, I just purchased another one, so I guess the benefits still outweigh the down-sides. Either that, or I'm too lazy to research the competition.

  515. I like to keep myself trim, and for years I've been using my old Remington beard trimmer to also trim my legs so that they don't look like a human forest. That Remington trimmer worked GREAT for years until it reached the end of its life. So, I did the research, and bought a separate beard trimmer (the Philips Norelco Qt4070), and a separate body groomer which was this one. I like the fact that it was an all-in-one device...didn't have a million attachments. Big mistake. Both the Norelco BG2040 body trimmer and the Norelco QT4070 beard trimmer have a serious design flaw: the comb setting doesn't lock. So, if you try using any setting longer than 1 (the shortest), and you apply normal pressure to your skin, the comb will get pushed back to the shortest setting. Now, I don't want to be completely hairless...I just want to keep my fur in check. So, I use the longer settings (4 or 5) on my lower legs, the medium setting (3) on my armpits and..err..pubic area, and the lower settings (1, 2) on my upper legs. However, this is a VERY difficult task to do when the damn comb doesn't lock. You have to hold it in place!! As for the shaver side of it...it's okay. I never fully trust electric shavers anyways. When I want to mechanically shave something (like the back of my neck), I just remove the comb from the trimmer end, and use that side of it, and then I'll go over it again with the shaver side. The shaver side is only good for areas with very sparse hair. DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT. I wanna say that this is an overpriced product, but then I'd be saying that it's worth buying at a lower price, which isn't true. This isn't worth your money at ANY price. DO NOT BUY. I found a refurbished version of my old Remington beard trimmer here on Amazon, and will buy that for both beard and body. Too bad I wasted so much money on this one.
  516. I bought this item after my second Philips Norelco BG2020 broke. I decided to opt for the more expensive option hoping it will do a better job.<br />I mainly use the trimming head to shorten my body hair. Although the shaving head is exactly the same as the one on the BG2020 this guys seems to trim a smaller area than its predecessor. Moreover, the trimming head is hard to handle and my wrists start hurting after a while.<br />I used the shaving head a few times and cut myself with it for the first time.<br />All in all, this might be a good purchase for someone that mainly uses the shaving head and occasionally the trimming one. If I was you I would consider some of the lower cost options which are much better to handle and do a better job in my opinion.
  517. Let's be frank. If you're a guy, keeping your private areas clean is a must. But, if you are like me, you have no idea on the best way to do it. Let me tell you a way...get this product and read my review. Let's get \\"grooming.\\" Out of the box, you will need to charge the device for about half a day. But after that, you are ready to go. Now, as advertised, you can use this product both in and out of the shower. From my experience, I would advise doing it in the shower for two reasons: 1) You're going to want to get in the shower after you use it anyway, and 2) it's a lot less messy. So, after jumping in the shower, soap up and clean rinse yourself off. Now, I would HIGHLY recommend using some sort of lather such as a shaving cream for doing the actual grooming. It is much less painful (although to be fair...using this product dry is not painful to begin with). With the shaving cream you will notice much less tug and pull. Now for the graphic parts, after putting shaving cream where you are going to be working, take the Bodygroomer and just use it like you would a normal razer. My preferred method is to just in a patch of hair and then rise...then repeat. It's very effortless. It might take some time to get it the way you want, but the adjustable attachment and pivoting head will have you in and out of the shower in 10 minutes. Now, for the harder to reach places...between your butt, it will even work there. Same concept, use some shaving cream and get to work, just go slow or you might do something you will regret. And lastly, for the family jewels. Honestly, it's the same idea. Get some shaving cream and with your other hand help flatten out the skin of your jewels and slowly move over it. It will work with no problems. I have been using this for month now and not once have I ever cut myself. Just remember to pay attention while you are using this...concentrate and you will be fine. Results: after the first day of use, the hair was still smooth andthere was no irritation. You will notice that you will not sweat as much down there and it will feel cleaner and fresher as you move around during the day. I'm sure you are skeptical that a product actually exists to solve all your \\"private\\" shaving needs, but this product is it. I would highly recommend it. I am several months in and have very, very happy with it. 5/5 stars. Amazing product. Amazing results.

The big problem, however, is that it does an awful job, completely missing hairs and entire patches and not providing nearly as close a shave as I'm used to. At some spots the shave is comparable to manual razor, while at other spots it's like two day's stubble. If this provided a comparable shave to a razor at the time savings it provides, it would be a great product. If it provided the shave it provides now, but saved 80% of the shaving time, it would be worth it. As it stands, this product is not worth using. Stick to the manual razor.

It's lightweight and easy to use. The pivot head is just enough flex to get the curves of my chin and face and the trimmer on the other end is great for a stubble week. What I found was it does get a smooth skin finish, but it comes with all the downfalls of using a straight edge razor (ie: ingrown hairs). It seems that nothing for me these days can give me a perfectly smooth finish without irritation. I will say though that the mini-clippers gave me the closest shave I've ever had, but it also took me more than 2x as long to shave (when compared with using normal hair clippers). After only 1 use, I went back to using my normal hair clippers as the irritation coupled with the 2x time trimming wasn't worth it to get such a close shave.<br />I will also note that I have used this as a facial shaver & it works great, but takes a while to shave compared to conventional gel & razor shaving.   620. I used an electric razor to shave my face when I was a teenager; back then all electrics were dry-shave only. If you tried to shave in the shower, you'd ruin your razor or worse. So, naturally, the first thing I did with this razor was try to shave dry skin. BIG mistake. I got nicked up pretty badly, and was still left with stubble for all my efforts. On dry skin, the foil sticks to your skin, tilting the head and causing the side cutters dig in, nicking the skin. I think one of the cheaper models without the floating head would work better for this, since you could keep the foil level even on dry skin.<br /><br />I was very disappointed and was about to toss the thing, but I decided to try it wet. I know shaving my face with a blade works better if the hairs have softened, so I took a long, hot bath and lathered myself up.<br /><br />With proper lubrication, the razor does a pretty decent job, comparable to a Gillette Trac-II blade razor (which costs under $1). I can get an even smoother shave if I spend a great deal of time (10-15 minutes), but this really isn't practical for daily use.<br /><br />While trying to shave my &#34;coin purse&#34;, it feels like I'm getting nicked up, but there's no blood or any visible injury. I think it's just grabbing and yanking the hairs, creating a sharp pinching sensation. I find myself shaving everything else with the BodyGroom and using the Gillette for that one area.<br /><br />It's also too large and unwieldy to use between the cheeks, another area where the simple razor blade wins again.<br /><br />My recommendation would be to skip this particular model. If you're confident and competent with a blade, go that route, it's cheaper and faster. If rubbing something sharp across your family jewels makes you cross your legs in terror, buy one of the less expensive models like the BG2038 or BG2028. They all use the same foil unit and the fixed head might actually be easier to use, particularly dry.

  676. Let's start with a little background. I've gone through a couple different shavers and trimmers, from: Norelco, Braun, Wahl, Gillette, and Panasonic. I've had favorites and also some that I'd definitely steer away from. In a nutshell, I highly recommend this BodyGroom Pro. I am able to safely and efficiently trim down the hair, and then subsequently shave it off with the other end. I did get experience a little nick, but that was my own fault. Overall, I've been thoroughly impressed with the quality!<br />--------------<br /><br />More detail:<br /><br />Let me make a point: I am blessed with the &#34;lots of hair, all-over, grows back way too fast&#34; situation -- something I'm not bragging about.<br /><br />With my schedule, trimming the &#34;bod&#34; requires two nights. I'll start with the shortest setting on the blade guard, working my way down. I'll start shaving &#34;with the grain&#34; (in the direction of the hair), and then also against the grain (opposite direction). Afterwards, I'll remove the blade guard and shave over, against the grain, the areas to get the finest trim possible. Once satisfied, I can switch over to the shave-end and take care of business.<br /><br />This method works incredibly well and so far I've been really happy with the results!<br /><br />With respect to trimming/shaving the &#34;jewels,&#34; technique is the most important. You definitely need to trim with the blade guard first. It's vital to stretch out the area you are shaving, as that will result in the most effective trim. Same technique with the shave-end!<br /><br />When trimming/shaving, be confident. Slow and controlled movements are the way to go. Also, you'll be able to feel if something 'bad' is going to happen (like a nick or pull), so you can stop and adjust accordingly when that feeling happens.<br /><br />Enjoy this trimmer/shaver, it's a great investment!<br /><br />Cheers.

  693. Owned this product for 3 years. Bought in from Amazon Austria.<br /><br />Never had much success with the shaving head.<br />Took to long to get a clean shave an my balls or chest, and got cut or scratched multiple times in the process.<br />Switched to a regular safety razor and received much cleaner results, without cutting myself in the process.<br />The trimming side works well. I mostly used it to trim my thick leg hairs without them looking stubbly or clean-shaven.<br /><br />Sadly the battery service time was a disappointment as well. I often had to stop and recharge during usage.<br />&#34;Was&#34; because the product refused to charge after 3 years using the included charger, and I never bothered replacing them.<br /><br />Looking forward, I wouldn't buy this product again.   694. Because of how the trimmer sections stick out on the shaver end, I do not see how you can shave in any area that is tight without nicking yourself with the trimmer sections. This seems like a really poor design to me. Clearly, others love this device but I do not see what they see in it. It seems well made but where those two trimmers are seems to make the shaver part unusable in tight areas, which means seeing blood.<br /><br />The stand is also a dumb design. Most shavers and trimmer have just the unit itself and a cord for charging it. This gives you this nice, fold out stand. Problem is you cannot charge the device without the stand because the stand conducts the electricity. Hence, unless you love the idea of displaying your bodygroom pro on your counter, you will have to keep track of three things, not two, and get out three things, not two, when you want to charge the device.<br /><br />I think the unit is well made. It's just got design issues that make it something I wish I had not purchased.<br /><br />Comes with 45 day money back warranty from Norelco. I called to take advantage of this. Person took all my information. They (Norelco) did not follow up further as they said they would. Terrible service.
  695. This shaver is super fast for body shaving and easy to clean. It's also really nice that is is chargeable so you don't have to run through tons of batteries.

But even on the shortest setting I noticed it didn't really cut evenly and I had to go back and forth several times for the easiest of trimming on some arm hair which is very fine and light and easy to cut typically with my hair trimmer. But for now I'll have to keep using them, which incidentally I had to use to fix what this trimmer couldn't get on my arms adequately/evenly.   732. In theory, this should be a great product. Unfortunately, it falls short in a few areas.<br /><br />First, and most importantly is in battery life. No matter how long or short it charges for, the trimming side always has very little battery power and the yellow light almost immediately comes on. This started happening perhaps a month into its use. Weird thing is that if you shut the trimmer off and turn the close shave side on, the battery magically comes back to life. Reading reviews of other similar universal products, this seems to be a very common issue. Again, very unfortunate because on paper, this is an amazing product.<br /><br />Second, be very careful using either side of this shaver below the belt. I won't go into details but it can be a bloody mess (pun intended).<br /><br />Third, it doesn't come close to giving you a smooth shave. It'll get you down past stubble, but in places like your neck and other areas, it's not going to do what you're hoping it will.<br /><br />Lasty, I did not receive the 3 additional attachments shown in the photos, so I was stuck with the only adjustable beard trimmer. leaving the choice of a 5 day long beard, or an awkward stubble if i took the attachment off altogether.<br /><br />In conclusion, it's worth the $30-40 bucks you can save on having it do a lot of razor work.

  775. I had the older BG2020 before upgrading to this new trimmer. I thought the BG2020 was fantastic and I was weary at first to try an &#34;upgraded&#34; model in case it didn't work as well. I upgraded because the screen clamps on the BG2020 wore out and I couldn't keep the screen on any longer.<br /><br />The BG2040 feels more sturdy than my BG2020. It trims very well, probably better than the 2020. The only problem I have with the 2040 is that it tugs on longer hair if I move to fast, which is something I never had a problem with on the 2020. (That is the only reason for missing one star.) If I move the trimmer slowly or use the other end to pre-trim I don't tug any hair. Also I have yet to nick myself with this trimmer, which is very nice when you shave sensitive areas.<br /><br />Also the other end is fantastic. I like having as few trimmers as possible and this has pretty much replaced my old beard and hair trimmer. I shave my entire head to a 2, and the settings on this are a little shorter than normal trimmers, so I place the setting to a 3 and am able to get a nice shave on the top of my head and beard.
  776. After searching for hours upon hours, I finally bit the bullet and bought this personal groomer. So far, I have not had any issues with the adjustable trimmer sliding down to the lowest setting when trimming hair and the trimmer is by far my favorite side of the groomer. Never had any snags or pulls. Always very smooth and a good looking cut. The shaving side takes a little practice and getting used to, but overall works very well and does an outstanding job. The swivel head works very well for any shaving in tight spaces. I had the model before this and I believe that the shaving on that was a little bit better, but it died. Also it charges very quickly and I have never had it die on me mid-trim. Overall, I am thoroughly pleased with my purchase and would recommend to any guy that is trying to get into some body hair management.
  777. I hate to admit it, as I've always thought of myself as a rather &#34;manly&#34; man, but I really like having no extra hair (or cleanly trimmed, at least). I tried shaving for the first time earlier this year with a standard razor like what ladies use, and I tore myself up. Then, I tried an epilator (which looks like a shaver, but just pulls the hair out completely), and while this is the best removal method, it's painful and very time-consuming. Worse, with epilating, when the hairs start growing back, they tend to curl up under the skin.<br /><br />This body groomer is just the perfect balance. It doesn't last as long as epilating, but it's comfortable and effective. I only tried it on my chest and abs, and I like the results, but will try it in the shower another time. I have high expectations, and I believe I won't be let down. If I experience otherwise, I'll update this review.

I am talking about five to ten minutes of usage then turning it off then trying to turn it back on again after a week off and getting no response. Why is it if I leave this unplugged and unused after just being fully charged does this lose its charge in just under a couple days?
  780. First of all: this shaver is long enough, and because the shaver end cuts at its edges as well, that one can shave those areas on the back impossible to reach (without help) with a razor. Admittedly, I can only just barely get between my shoulder blades with my reach and flexibility--but barely means it does. That alone make it a winner, to me.<br />To elaborate, it trims EVERYthing well (as previously observed by other reviewers). Some men don't mind having hair on every square inch of their bodies. Some men (can't see it myself) LIKE that. Myself, I like a clean, smooth feel (perhaps I was a Roman in a previous lifetime) and have relied on my razor for decades. A razor can't reach the back; is inefficient on longer hair like arms and is dangerous in--ah--certain places. This shaver does everything and does it supremely well. 'Nuff said.

  797. This is a very solid shaver specifically designed for removing body hair. Instead of the typical Norelco lay-out of 2 or 3 round heads, it uses a slim cylindrical head more often seen in Braun or Panasonic products. The shaving head can both pivot and telescope; Thus it can follow the body curvature very well. The product itself is solidly built and ergonomically shaped. Perhaps because Norelco is trying to invade a competitor stronghold, the price is set surprisingly low for a premium brand. Overall, it is both a very good product and a very good bargain.

It is now dead completely, and I've been using regular clippers and an old shaver to help trim different areas.<br /><br />This product was not stored in harsh environments, always inside the bathroom drawer, away from harmful elements.   877. When my old Norelco sideburns trimmer died on my, I was researching for a replacement. The old one lasted more than a decade and cost me $37 (bought in 1999, died in 2012). This BodyGroom 7100, however, quit working on me after two years and cost me $54.88 at the time. I am not currently generating income, so I tried to fix it. At first, I spent half-hour just to take the blade apart, and I cleaned the sideburns trimmings, which I thought to be the issue. And the trimmer worked again for a couple more days before it quit again. Now I put some mineral oil in it, and it works again (for now). So yeah, if your BodyGroom quit on you, try that first.<br /><br />A second issue I have with this model since the day one was, it can only work in &#34;wireless&#34; mode. You can't trim your sideburns while plugged into the outlet. I understand it's probably because it's intended to be used wet, so such design will prevent accidental electrocution, but I prefer having the option to plug in, so it doesn't die on me in the middle of things. I didn't actually do an exact measure, but it's around the neighborhood of 30 minutes per full charge. It might not be enough juice for a full body grooming for some of you, so be aware of that.<br /><br />The charging unit is badly designed. It's lightweight and can tip over easily, given the groomer itself has a nice weight to it. And there is no holder for the power wire to keep it in place. Combine all those designed flaws, and you get a unit that can tip over very easily.<br /><br />As for the unit itself for doing its job, I guess it's okay. That's why the three stars. Still wish for a plug-in mode, so it has more power.

I will never buy your products again.

  920. I'm a guy. A guy that wondered for years how it was done. You know, how a man can have absolutely no hair down there (below the belt, above the knees). Did they use hair remover creams? Did they (gulp) wax? Did they pluck? Did they use electric clippers? Did they use a disposable razor? Electric shaver?<br /><br />I'm also a guy that has tried his electric beard trimmer/shaver and the flip-up clippers on the back. It never turned out well. It was scary. I knicked myself every time I tried (drawing blood in the process). I liken my attempts to taking outdoor power-shears to tissue paper.<br /><br />So, if your like me, you have hair you don't want down there. It makes you sweat and smell, and it's just plain ugly. Your skin in this region, however, is extremely soft and extremely thin. You've tried other methods and have given up every time (with fear of doing something horrible).<br /><br />So imagine my surprise (and skepticism) when I happened upon this product on Amazon. I thought; yeah right, there is no way an electric anything could shave me down there without serious harm, rash, or worse. And then I read all the wonderful reviews on this product by other Amazon customers who came before me (my favorite thing about Amazon). After reading all the positive reviews I convinced myself to just try it; and write an honest review for all the skeptic guys out there (like me) that don't believe there really could be a device that could actually work for them.<br /><br />My first experience:<br />I received my product quickly. According to the directions, it needed to be charged first - dang it! Fast forward one day; shaver fully charged. Before my shower, I sat down on my favorite throne (aka 'toilet') in the house (in my birthday suit), said a short prayer, built up my confidence, and gave it a shot. I took it slow at first, convinced it would end in disaster. And then, I couldn't believe my eyes... IT WORKED! Not a knick, not a rash - just smooth hairless skin. In fact, it worked so well, so fast, I couldn't stop myself. Which is why the top half of my thighs are also hairless now. To my surprise, to my bewilderment, this thing really works, and better than I imagined. IT REALLY DOES. The reviews on this product are TRUE! And yes, I shaved it ALL - the bolt, the nuts, the bag they came in. It's all hairless now, and its SMOOTH. Not even stubble left behind. It's as smooth as my face feels right after a good shave; smooth as a baby's bottom. It's an unusual feeling to have no hair down there, and I love it.<br /><br />After 2 days:<br />Still hairless, still smooth (unlike my face which has stubble within hours of shaving). Still no rash (another surprise). I've noticed I haven't sweated as much down there, and there is no longer a yucky smell after a day of activity. In fact, it's been 2 days since my last shower, and I still actually feel kinda clean down there. Crazy, I know.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />Guys, don't hesitate any longer on this purchase. JUST BUY IT. If your not satisfied, just return it. But really, EVERY MAN NEEDS THIS, PERIOD. I'm baffled that this thing isn't marketed more to men. More of us need to hear about this device. It should be taught about in school!<br /><br />Anyways, I am so happy I took a chance on this product. I hope every guy out there gets one of these and has the same experience I have. What more can I say? I'll be confidently recommending this one to all my guy friends, including you guys.<br /><br />***************************<br /> UPDATE: SEPTEMBER 2012<br />***************************<br />I wrote my original review on this product in January 2011. I've now owned these for a total of 1 year, 8 months.<br /><br />With exception to a shortened battery life (I have to recharge before use), it still operates and looks as good as the day I received it. I am extremely satisfied with this purchase and the price I paid. If you're looking for a quality, effective pair of \\"body\\" clippers; theseare definately highly recommend by me.<br /><br />I'm a very pleased, very impressed, and very satisfied customer.<br /><br />Thanks Philips Norelco. We appreciate quality products at fair prices. Please keep it up and never give up on quality.<br /><br />[...]<br />I hope this review gives you some insight and help with your choice, and a little knowledge from an unbiased owner.   925. If you're reading this, you're probably as excited about this product as I was, after reading all the glowing reviews of it. Unfortunately, I ignored the negative reviews, and now I wish I hadn't. Oh, let me tell you the ways that this product has disappointed me: -Numero uno: The GIANT gash in an incredibly sensitive area on my body, courtesy of using the shaving end. Who ARE these other reviewers who say that it's impossible to cut yourself with this product?! I was very, very careful with how I used the groomer. I went very slowly, followed the instructions, and did all the necessary prep. Even before I cut myself, I felt very uneasy having this groomer down there, and you might feel that way, too. My instincts told me that it was a bad idea to have something sharp, electric, and buzzing near my nads, and I should've listened, because my instincts were right. i figure that if I'm gay, and even I am unable to use a grooming product successfully, then there's no hope for all the straight guys out there, and the product's gotta be flawed. Plus, a nick or two I can understand, but seriously, my wound is definitely full-on gash status, people. Ouch. (And in case you're curious, I tried the shaver both wet and dry. Gash was courtesy of the wet shave, and I pinched and nicked myself a couple times when using it dry. I didn't notice much of a difference between the two styles. I was lucky I didn't cut myself with it dry, too.) -Two: The inefficiency of the shaver. Let me recreate for you what happened most of the time I used the shaver, when I wasn't busy getting a giant cut: 1) I see a couple of short hairs, all on their lonesome, begging to be shaved. 2) I try shaving the area. 3) Nothing happens. Hairs remain standing. 4) I try a different angle. 5) Nothing happens. 6) I try a different angle again. 7) Nothing happens. 8) I try the last possible angle available to me, short of bending the space-time continuum. 9) Nothing happens. The hairs are STILL there. 10) I sigh and give up. So let me get this straight: When I use this shaver, either it cuts so close that it makes a crater in my skin, or it's so far off that in FOUR different attempts it can't even shave two little hairs that a normal razor could easily pick off? So wait, what's the point of this thing? -Three: The trimmer is decent, but could be better. As opposed to the completely useless shaver, the trimmer did have some value. I was able to trim a lot of areas on my chest, back, and no-no zone that needed some tending. And it wasn't too much of a hassle. But I found, particularly in my groin area, that the trimmer didn't always work. There are some odd angles down there that make it hard to bring the trimmer across the skin. This isn't entirely the body groomer's fault, obviously, but I figure if the thing's job is to trim body hair (and we all know what specific region of body hair that most buyers are interested in trimming), then it better be designed in such a way as to make that a little simpler. It seems to me, though, that the trimmer head is a little too wide to be able to line up properly with areas in the groin. There's not always a lot of surface area to work with, and the designers of the product should have accommodated that circumstance better. -Four: Price. Enough said. I'd really encourage you to think about what you want from this product before buying it. If you're interested primarily in trimming hair outside of the groin, then fantastic! This is a great product for that. If you want to trim body hair and groin hair, then this is a decent product, but know that it can get a little tricky when it comes to trimming groin hair. If you want to shave close and be bare in all your unholiest places, then I think you'll be disappointed with this product. I've had more success with disposable single blade razors for sensitive skin that I bought from CVS. Yes, it takes longer than a fancy and chic electric razor (I know, I was hoping to avoidthe wet shave with this groomer, too, you know), but it'll get the job done, you'll save some money, and you probably won't end up with a band-aid on your balls. Thanks for reading.

  929. This little gadget does everything it says it can. On one end is an adjustable clipper for trimming hair; on the other end is the shaver head for removing all hair down to the skin. It's touted for use from the neck down, but I'd bet it would do a fair job of shaving one's head, if that's your thing.<br /><br />Lessons learned from use: don't press the shaver hard against the skin. Use light pressure and make several passes (much like using a regular electric shaver on your face). If you're using it on an area where the skin is loose (think you know where I mean), &#34;stretch&#34; the skin moderately tight with one hand while using the shaver with the other. That way, you don't nick anything and there's virtually no skin irritation. The heads detach for easy cleaning.<br /><br />The instructions are specific about charging the battery. To avoid shortening the battery charge capacity, they tell you NOT to charge it after each use. Use it repeatedly without recharging until you see it's indicator light flash orange - that means there's 10 minutes of run time left and it's time to recharge it. When you plug the charger in, the indicator light will flash green while charging; when fully charged, the light shows steady green. They recommend that once or twice a year you run the unit all the way down to a dead battery and then recharge it. I just did that (for the first time) and it fully recharged in exactly one hour as advertised. Pretty simple.

  965. I used to use a pair of scissors and disposable razors to keep my underarms and nether regions \\"hair-free\\" and in the process had experienced my fair share of cuts, burns and frustration. So, in 2011 I bought this groomer after some research and haven't had to look back since.<br /><br />Its shape is great to hold and the pivoting head can navigate through the treacherous regions like a good 4WD off road vehicle. The charging is cord-free, and the battery has yet to give me any troubles in terms of holding its charge or running out before I was done, and it typically takes a good half an hour or more to complete one \\"session\\"<br /><br />The trimmer works well for mowing the longer hair. I keep an extra pair of head, for sometimes in a pinch, I have even shaved my face with it, and it did do a pretty good job there too.<br /><br />It truly is 100% waterproof in that I can use it in the shower and cleaning becomes a breeze. to clean the head I will sometimes take the head off and use a can of compressed air - this really works well.<br /><br />I have become so accustomed to using it, that at this point this is a necessity for me. I will highly recommend it to anyone looking for an all-around groomer.
  966. This was advertised to be a clean shave, but at least for me it leaves a bit of stubble whether I use it wet or dry, against or with the grain, with or without shave lotion. I do like the trimmer side much better, great for touching up the eyebrows and 'stache, just not as impressed with the shaver as I had hoped.
  967. I'm writing this review for an, ummm, friend. Yea, that's it. I would never manscape and I don't know how this shows as being an Amazon Verified Purchase for me...<br /><br />This trimmer has been used twice and works really well. Battery life was more than enough for armpits, front torso and nether region. The instructions for removing the foil were poor and I cut my finger the first time. The easiest way that I've found is to put my fingernail under the grey plastic piece on one of the corners and pry/pop the foil off. I use the trimmer end for armpits and the foil end for everything else. The key with the foil end is to go slow and steady, keeping the skin as smooth as you can. Also consider that a stray short-hair here and there might be an acceptable alternative to potentially drawing blood in bumpier regions. I've only used it dry and believe that's probably the easier way.
  968. This is the tool you have been looking for! Stop reading reviews and order it now. Going on a year and nothing bad to report. Easy on the nether regions.
  969. This is a very nice product. Have searched all over for a good quality trimmer and this really fits the description. The materials used on the build are great and I love the versatility of having the two ends dedicated to different tasks. I have used other trimmers and got cut on sensitive areas. This one didn't get me cut and actually exceeded my expectations on trim quality.
  970. While this razor would make a great beard trimmer, it is lacking in the body trimmer section, mainly because it doesn't provide a very close shave, especially with the buzzer side. The features it has are all well and good, the cool charging cradle works well, and it's very nice to be waterproof, but the plastic adapter that covers the bottom part is simply too big, they need to include another one that is about half as thick, even on it's lowest setting its leaving a significant amount of hair, and if you take it off you're going to cut yourself.
  971. There are a couple things I don't like. The trimmer end could have finer blades on it (I'm used to the Wahl personal grooming trimmer). Also the shaver end could be higher quality. It seems a bit cheap and I can confirm the comments about not being capable of a close shave.<br />But I still like it. The dual ends is cool. I'm not into the head changing (and they usually are really cheaply made). This is a solid personal appliance. Other than the shaver foil itself, everything is well built and nice materials. I really like the brushed metal body. It's ergonomic, and easy to handle (all around your body). Not a real good close shave, but I'm not a businessman, so it works for me.

  978. I had two of these, the first got left at a hotel and I liked it enough to get another. The second one after just a few months got really weak which means pulled hairs. It works ok as a body groomer but the guide is too rounded to get hairs to stand up for a good cut. I use a wahl clipper set for this task since it has a much better guard. The shaver doesn't work well at all unless you want to go over the same spot a bunch of times. Finally after about 6 months the second one really started to work slow and barely take a charge before it broke completely and just got hot when put on the charger. I bought a different groomer this time, not worth it for something that only lasted a few months at 100%.
  979. This product got the job done, but I would not say it was perfect in any way. I'm not a person paid to give a review to this product or anything, this is my honest opinion. I had long hair on my arms and armpits. I tried the trimmer part, but it didn't work very well. I don't think I really understand how to use the trimmer. I read the instructions, but it didn't help. The shaver part is my favorite. It mowed down my long hairs on my legs, belly button area, arms, and armpits. However, the annoying thing is that you have to shave over the same areas multiple times. You have to look at your arm from different angles to catch hairs you couldn't see before. Also, the lighting of the room you are in does matter. I walked out into my living room after shaving where there was natural light coming through the window and the light made hairs show up like magic that I couldn't see before in my bathroom. It was irritating that I had to shave off the missed hairs in all these random places, but I'm some what of a perfectionist. I recommend buying it, but just be prepared to spend at least more than an hour doing a full shave if you want it looking perfect (arms, legs, armpits, feet, private area, and belly button area). As I said, it is able to get the job done, but at the expense of irritating you from time to time.

  983. the battery lasts for 1 shave, then the next time you charge it be prepared for less than 5 minutes of shave time. After that, not even 10 seconds. I've asked management to contact me back, but I never heard from anyone at Norelco (plus I've sent all of the units back for testing. I paid about $80 for a shaving device that I got zero use out of.
  984. Because of how the trimmer sections stick out on the shaver end, I do not see how you can shave in any area that is tight without nicking yourself with the trimmer sections. This seems like a really poor design to me. Clearly, others love this device but I do not see what they see in it. It seems well made but where those two trimmers are seems to make the shaver part unusable in tight areas, which means seeing blood. The stand is also a dumb design. Most shavers and trimmer have just the unit itself and a cord for charging it. This gives you this nice, fold out stand. Problem is you cannot charge the device without the stand because the stand conducts the electricity. Hence, unless you love the idea of displaying your bodygroom pro on your counter, you will have to keep track of three things, not two, and get out three things, not two, when you want to charge the device. I think the unit is well made. It's just got design issues that make it something I wish I had not purchased. Comes with 45 day money back warranty from Norelco. I called to take advantage of this. Person took all my information. They (Norelco) did not follow up further as they said they would. Terrible service. Update months later. I tried to return to Norelco with their 45 day warranty. Nothing. No follow through. No money back. The device is a loser and the company seems worse.

  1114. The Body Groom Pro is a solid trimmer, the weight and solid feel are just right for long trimming and grooming sessions. The trimmer has five length settings that work well and lock into place fairly secure (you can make it slip with excess pressure) and holds well under normal use. The rounded edges of the guard, on the trimmer, slide smoothly over skin without scratching or pinching. Trimming of body hair (after your initial grooming) only takes two quick passes to maintain your desired results.<br /><br />The foil shaver does an adequate job; the shaver does leave some stubble behind but it is only noticeable if someone is a foot away from you. The results for the shaver may be better under wet conditions but I only use my Body Groom Pro outside the shower, so I can't speak to the results it provides under wet conditions.<br /><br />The unit holds a long charge; I have achieved 50-60 minutes of run time between charges (which will give you 3 or 4 trimming sessions before the need to recharge). The charger works fast; the charger only takes about an hour to fully charge and you're ready for another 50-60 minutes of use.<br /><br />Finally, cleaning is also quick and easy. Both the trimmer and foil shaver open easily (including the removable guard) and only take about a minute to clean.

Terribly stupid design flaw in an otherwise great product.<br /><br />As a result I only ever use no length or the lowest length (rests against trimmer surface) to guarantee accuracy.

However, on this model they added a swivel to the shaving side head, which in my opinion makes it more difficult to shave the hard to reach areas because somethings always swiveling away from where you want it to go.<br /><br />I also find that the shaver doesn't cut quite as close (or quite as good/efficiently) as the previous model. I find myself having to go over areas more than I would on the other model to get the same result. But other than that it's still the best groomer you can find right now. If you have the older model and it's still working great, I see no reason to upgrade to this.   1149. This is most definitely the best Bodygrooming device that I have used. Very easy to use, well constructed body shaver at a fairly reasonable price. I think most of the negative feedback regarding this product revolves around the life of the battery. But, some people might expect electronics to last far longer, and assume this will be the last body shaver they purchase in their lifetime. I will be happy if I get about 2 years of life out of this product...if that happens, then this shaver will have far exceeded my expectations. I tend to believe that if you follow cleaning , maintenance, and charging instructions, that electronics usually hold up fairly well over time. Another gripe that I've seen on the reviews for this product are in reference to the ineffectiveness of the trimmer features of the unit. I thought the trimmer worked most excellent, but I would advise taking the time to trim longer body hair with scissors before using the trimmer on this shaver. It will operate better, and pregrooming will reduce hair from pulling or tugging, or clogging the blade.<br /><br />Personally, the only flaw I could point to with this product are with the cleaning instructions being a bit vague about how to remove foil shaver in order to clean the unit. The picture is accurate, in the portrayal of the motion necessary to remove foil shaver, but a bit more direction in regards to this would be helpful. A 15 sec video? All I am saying, is that I could easily see someone unintentionally damaging foil head because the directions are not very clear.<br /><br />Overall, this shaver is well worth the money spent. Saved considerable amount of time grooming, and offers outstanding pain free shaving results. I have sensitive skin...and no red bumps from the use of this shaver. I definitely recommend this product.

So, as a lady, I have previously owned and loved a Panasonic lady's shaver, but wanted to see if I could find something that was shaped better - ie. could be held in different, less awkward angles and get the same effective trimmage. I decided to check out a man's shaver and see how that goes. Very scary to use the trimmer edge around the ladybits, but if you go slowly and angle properly you shan't get nicked. Cuts fairly close as well. Overall, so far so good. Will update after varied uses.
  1161. Yes I bought this about 3.5 years ago, so I can't complain much, but it's dead in the water as of 4 months ago. Really seems like the battery life should be better for a rarely used groomer. My older Norelco 3-headed shaving razor is older and still has plenty of life. To cap it off, it requires 'surgery' to replace the battery, no simple way to update that part. It works as advertised, just would prefer to see it work longer or be user serviceable.
  1162. I've owned many of the other BodyGroom models, and this model is by far the best. My previous BodyGroom had issues with the razor head popping off. This is well built and does a much better job without razor burn or hair pulling. I believe the pivoting head makes a big difference with comfort and efficiency. Good buy--I'd recommend this model of all the BodyGroom shavers.
  1163. Title pretty much says it all. There is definitely a lot to the bodygroom, and it does most things well enough, but none quite as well a dedicated tool. I'll break it down: The Trimmer: Works almost as well as the trimmer this replaced ([[ASIN:B001GQ3GEY Wahl Lithium Ion All In One Trimmer]]) and the comb is much smoother, that is, it doesn't scratch my skin as I use it. The maximum length setting (5) is more than long enough for anything I'd ever use the trimmer for. The minimum length, however, is not quite as short as I'd like. My old razor had an attachment that was about 1/2 the length and it was really useful getting a nice smooth fade along my neck. I'm still able to get the fade, I just have to take the comb off and be extra careful. The Shaver: The foil is decent enough that it gets the job done but, just like the trimmer, it's not as good as other electric shavers I've had in the past. It required a few extra passes to get everything sufficiently shaved. The precision trimmer, similarly, works well enough that I'm not complaining, but not quite as good as other trimmers I've owned. I've found there's a nice rocking action to the shaver end and it works really well on large expanses that I keep hairless. Basically, on the up stroke (against the grain), it rocks so the trimmer clears away any longer hairs and/or fuzz; then on the down stroke, the foil finishes the job. That alone cuts the time needed to clear such expanses in half as well as eliminates the need for a separate manual razor. Overall: The one thing the bodygroom absolutely excels at is its sheer versatility. You can be using the trimmer side one second, and the next be using the foil. All you have to do is push the button to turn the trimmer off, flip it over, push the button to turn the foil on, and you're on your way. Another huge plus is the utter lack of attachments. Coming from the Wahl with 19 bazillion attachments, it'll be nice to not have to carry a separate ziplock bag with the attachments whenever I travel. One thing I will miss about the Wahl (at least when it was new), is the amazing battery life. It would last a few weeks (5-6 full trims) on a single charge. I'm not sure about the battery life for this one yet as I've only used it once, but I was able to do a full trim (15-20 min) basically straight out of the box even though the manual said to charge it for 10 hours first. So, in summary: Pros: Jack of all trades easy to clean switches between functions super fast super sweet rocking action on the shaver end NO ATTACHMENTS! battery life seems more than adequate in my limited use so far Cons: Master of none kinda big which makes it somewhat difficult to maneuver in tight spaces such as between the legs
  1164. To keep this rather short, it does what Philips says it will do. It looks and performs good, and has many features (it's an all-in-one machine!) that will help grooming of any area. While the \\"manual\\" says it's not intended to be used above the neck, it does still also work great for trimming your beard or side burns. It also works great for the chest. It just takes some time.<br /><br />The trimmer will easily remove the hair that's been there for a few months. To get the rest though, it will take some time, if you want it to be baby smooth. The shaver head will indeed get rid of your hair and make your skin nice and smooth (and WITHOUT any irritation, to boot!), but as stated, it will take quite a few passes before it can remove all the stubble that was left from the trimmer end. You can't expect to just power through the stubble with the shaver end, otherwise you won't get it all...or worse, you'll yank some of the hairs while trying.<br /><br />Cleaning and charging is a breeze, and have had no problems thus far. The battery life seems average so far. Nothing special. Sometime it will sound as if it's going to die soon, but it will still go for a bit longer. So that's nice. I will usually charge it after usage, and then when I go to use it again (a week later), it has no problem grooming my areas all in one charge. Just don't expect to be able to do a couple days in a row, without charging it.<br /><br />Lastly, as expected, this can still cause some razor burn or draw some blood if you're not too careful in the sensitive areas. It will just take some finesse (and perhaps some satisfaction of not getting SOME areas as smooth as you'd like)...or maybe I just need some tougher skin.<br /><br />UPDATE #1: I've been using this about once a week (or every other week) for the past year. (I've owned it for just over a year now). The battery life has gone down a bit, but I can still get a the job done on one charge. HOWEVER, don't expect to be able to do your whole body on one charge after using this on a normal basis for a year. I've found that now it will basically last long enough to take care of the \\"sensitive\\" areas, and a little more -- say chest and/or stomach. But that's about it. Don't expect to be able to make yourself spic-and-span from the neck down if you're quite hairy from the neck down. It'll take a full-charge, plus another partial charge (I've found this out the hard way). If you're just maintaining those areas, you should be fine, but if you've let them grow out and expect to hit them all in one charge, you'll be disappointed. I've learned to deal with it, and adjust my \\"schedule\\" accordingly. With that said, part of the short battery-life may be because I charge it AFTER I'm done using it...and then won't use it again until a week later. Perhaps if I just waited until I NEEDED it, and then just charged it right before, it would be better on the battery. Not sure. I just wish there was also an AC Adapter \\"attachment\\" that we could use if needed.<br /><br />I also used this to \\"buzz\\" my entire head/scalp for the summer, and it worked just fine for that. No bogging down and no irritation from that.<br /><br />UPDATE #2: I've now had this for about 2 years. Battery life has suffered. I barely use it anymore. Maybe twice a month...and usually only to do some final trimming/detailing. I've been using hair clippers (more powerful and not reliant on a dead battery) for tougher jobs or when I let my body/face hair grow out. With that said, I ALWAYS have to charge this Norelco trimmer before use...otherwise it will die within minutes. However, even with a full charge, this trimmer is still not lasting long enough to do the job. I'm limited to one area of the body per charge. Also, the main reason for this update is that I have noticed while it is charging, the razor will actually TURN ITSELF ON for a few seconds. It's turning on the shaver (not trimmer) end for some reason. I take it off the charger and put it back on, but then an hour later it turned itself on again for a few seconds. Very strange.<br /><br />Update #3: Exactly 2 years later and this thing is totally dead. Won't even charge anymore. The green charging light doesn't come on, and when I turn the shaver on, it only lasts for a second. Pretty pathetic. The actual device and how it functions was great. The battery issues just kept getting worse and in turn caused me to constantly lower my rating.<br /><br />My device was JUST outside of the 2-year warranty. However, I contacted Philips and they were kind enough to still send me a replacement handle. Hopefully that will solve the issue.ut then an hour later it turned itself on again for a few seconds. Very strange.<br /><br />Update #3: Exactly 2 years later and this thing is totally dead. Won't even charge anymore. The green charging light doesn't come on, and when I turn the shaver on, it only lasts for a second. Pretty pathetic. The actual device and how it functions was great. The battery issues just kept getting worse and in turn caused me to constantly lower my rating.<br /><br />My device was JUST outside of the 2-year warranty. However, I contacted Philips and they were kind enough to still send me a replacement handle. Hopefully that will solve the issue.

  1184. I've been using this to shave my groin pumpkins and the surrounding regions for the last 1.5 years. This is far better and easier than using a regular shaver. I cannot recommend this enough. I use the pivoting end for the delicate bits (almost everything down there), and the fixed end I use at the longest setting to keep my leg hair in check. I nicked the pumpkins 2-4 times in the first half year of usage. Since then, I've had enough practice to know how to use the shaver and haven't nicked them since.<br /><br />TECHNIQUE:<br /><br />-The thinner and/or the more the skin folds, the lighter pressure you should apply. Don't apply any pressure at all near the thinnest, most fold-ey, most vulnberable skin, the shaver should skim a millimeter above such skin.<br /><br />-Use the edge trimmer to lightly skim the skin of the sack. The most vulnerable and risky part to shave is the part of the sack directly on and below the shaft.<br /><br />-Always shave against the direction the hairs point.<br /><br />-The skin on the pubic mound and between the leg and the sack are thick and tight enough to use the shaving foil for an extra close shave. Be cautious when doing the perineum, the part in between the scrotum and the backend, its bumpy.<br /><br />-Shaving gel is better than shaving dry. Its best to let your skin soak in warm water in order for the hair folicles to relax, however its easier shaving the sack when its cold, which causes the skin to pull tight. The best is to soak in warm water, come out of the water, apply shave gel, and shave everything except the sack. By the time you've done that, hopefully your landing gear will be up due to the cold air on them, the skin is tight, and you can have an easy and safe shave.
  1185. Works as advertised, doesn't leave you irritated like other razors and does not cause ingrown hairs like using a regular razor.   1270. Like every other guy that's sure to be reading this review, I was looking for easier ways to keep.... things... cleaned up. I read many of the glowing reviews here, and decided to drop the cash and hope for the best. Bad idea.<br /><br />There are really only two things that this item does well:<br />-Trim back 'the bush'<br />-Minimize the chances of cutting yourself (compared to a razor)<br /><br />When it comes to the first, you can use any pair of hair clippers to do just as good of a job (and probably cheaper). The good side for this item is it's battery powered and works in the shower.<br /><br />When it comes to cutting, there is a reason I said 'minimizes'. There are still 4 places on the shaving side that can leave some quite brutal gashes if you're not careful (which you should be considering the target area). I would not trust this anywhere that isn't smooth and flat.<br /><br />What the rating boils down to however, is the fact that arguably the key feature of this item doesn't work. You cannot shave with it. At all. It'll cut the hair down to around a mm high, but this looks absolutely terrible. You cannot get a remotely close shave.<br /><br />I will be attempting to use it this week as an every-day tool, and see if things improve over time. If they do, the rating will rise. But as of now, it's looking like a return.<br /><br />Day three of the week edit: got fed up with it yesterday and ended up razor shaving. That actually made it work really well today though. You definitely have to shave every day with this tool, or things get too thick for it to shave. What seems to be the biggest issue is precision. I don't shave everything, and maintaining crisp lines with this tool is quite difficult.<br /><br />TL;DR: Still testing.

  1274. The BG2020 was a simple and effective unit and after it died after 11 months I requested warranty repair via phone.<br /><br />The Philips CSR was polite, understanding and effective. Explaining to me the BG2020 was discontinued she immediately shipped out the BG2040, which is superior in nearly every metric to the BG2020.<br /><br />The BG2040 is a noticeably better made product superior in manufacture and use (the motor vibrates less and is quieter and there is a charging light on the device. 50 minutes use from an hour charge, reportedly. While it does not use attachments, there is a removable adjustable attachment on the smaller end. The smaller end more easily navigates nooks and crannies and suits my needs better than the old BG2020 with attachments. The pivoting head on the larger end is a welcome feature I did not know I needed and makes for a much safer, smoother trim. (So far.)<br /><br />While $50 might seem a bit high for the actual item received, it is only a few dollars more than you might wish to pay, and if it works for at least 2 years it will be a good value. Having first hand experience with customer service, I am very confident that if anything goes wrong Philips will make it right.

This could be a product that should fit the needs of most men, but there are a few major limitations that prevent it from being worth the cost.<br /><br />Battery life - Apparently the trimmer end requires a significant amount of power to run, or it has its own battery that is defective, because no matter how long I charge the device, it starts to blink an orange warning light when the trimmer is running. The orange light is supposed to mean that there are 10 minutes left, but ever since I first started using the tool, the trimmer has not run longer than 15 minutes.<br /><br />Shaver angle - I may just have never gotten used to using the shaver portion properly, but it seems like I have trouble getting either of the trimmers at the right angle. Also, the head tilts unpredictably and there is no locking mechanism.<br /><br />Functionality - I realize that this device is not intended for beards, but I am frustrated by how poorly it performs anywhere above the collarbone. I do not expect it to perform a shave like my Braun razor, but I would like for it to trim side burns and shape my beard a bit, but both of those tasks are far beyond its capability. My other two complaints are based on the normal, expected usage of the device, but it is disappointing that they could not take it a bit further and design something that could handle any hair.<br /><br />I probably should have sent mine in for a replacement, but at this point I am going to look elsewhere for something that better suits my needs.

  1313. My first use was on my face, and the foil shaver did a decent job, so for those wondering, you can use it on your face. However, not sure if you'd want to use something on your face that you'll use on your junk too. I bought this to shave my denver nuggets without cutting them. This thing does the trick. Smooth as eggs with no nicks or cuts. Another person said it was starfish approved, and I'll have to concur with that. The teeth on the edge of the foil shaver don't move like a clipper, it's basically just a metal comb that probably lifts the hair so the foil shaver can cut them. You will not have to worry about cutting your junk if you buy this.
  1314. Purchased this item on April 30, 2010, and it is still going strong. Used in shower, wet and dry and nothing seems to stop it. It has not been babied at all. Even used in shower then tossed out on the rug on many occasions. Great product and obviously a beast. Will take care of any area that needs tamed. This device of self inflicted torture does not clip the hair, it catches it like a wad of gum. Then it gives a not so gentle tug on your follicles (just to let you know it's doing something and thus setting off the pain numbing endorphins held within each and every one of us!) all accompanied by that wonderful whirring sound to let you know that it is indeed powered up and that you are not just imagining that you turned it on.<br /><br />So, now pumped full of rage, endorphins, adrenaline, and an overall contempt for having to do this in the first place, I'm now ready for my wild night with the woman!   1317. Although this product is marketed for men, I bought it because of the majority of rave reviews. As it is designed to shave body hair, I thought it would work well for my legs and underarm areas. This shaver gave me pretty bad razor burn and also cut me badly in several places. I guess this is due to the edges of the blades being exposed as other reviewers have stated. I thought this was a characteristic of all electric shavers, but fortunately, it is not. I just purchased the Panasonic ES2207P shaver, and the difference is night and day. NO nicks or cuts, and a close shave with very few passes needed. If you are a lady, or a man who wouldn't mind a pink shaver, I would pass on this one and get the Panasonic ES2207P. The Panasonic is also more economical as it is priced below $20.

Otherwise, I'd give it a 5 star rating for actual functioning.<br /><br />UPDATE: After getting a new replacement unit from BB&B, the replacement has lasted less than 12 months and 4 light trims, and the battery is now unable to hold a charge. Totally unacceptable for a product this expensive. I'm going to try replacing the batteries myself with quality cells from an electronics store<br /><br />UPDATE: I replaced the batteries myself with NIMH Sanyo Eneloop AAA cells (2). No soldering is required but some disassembly is required. The original batteries were cheap junk.

  1325. This shaver is great, I've been using it for 9 months now. There is DEFINITELY a learning curve in using the shaver, and so you do need to be careful how you use it. The thing I did wrong once (and only once) is that I first tried to use the extension trimmer side on my genital area to get my hair shorter before using the close-shave double-blades. That was a BAD move - because the plastic guard has it's guard wings too far apart, it allows loose skin to get in between and the blade is not built for \\"bare\\" shaving... so my scrotum skin actually got caught and then was nicked by the blade and I bled enough to learn a hard lesson. But it wasn't a deep cut and it wasn't excruciating pain, it was just enough to learn I can't do it that way anymore.<br /><br />Also, it's very intimidating to use anything electric on your genitalia... It's hard to trust this shaver at first, especially when in my case when it had already \\"bitten\\" me on one of the first uses... I was jaded because of that. but I kept using it and I'm really glad now, because I use it all the time and gives me the results I want. Basically, I've learned that i can only use the extension trimmer to keep myself groomed in the area around the genitalia, but I MUST use the close-shave double-sided blades ON my genitalia. The blades on that side are built so that they are so close together, it's almost impossible for any skin (even loose skin) to get caught in between the blades. The blades are a micro-factor when it comes to distance between them, only separating enough to really get hair fibers in between them to cut.<br /><br />This electric shaver technically will NOT ever get you a shave as close to a razor will... but honestly, it's pretty darn close enough. Hair grows way too fast for me to want to use a razor that frequently around my genitalia, and if you use this shaver every day then it will be smooth enough. You really have to let your hair grow for like 3 days for it to be that noticeably rough downthere... but if you use this shaver daily or every other day even, you'll be happy with the smoothness it achieves especially considering the alternative is either a sharp razor to your skin, painful waxing, or using some chemical hair removers on your skin. No thanks!!! This little buddy is a fantastic solution to keeping a smooth, safe groom that you (and your lady) will love.

At first I thought it was the smoke detector. But it sounded more like an electric razor than a smoke alarm. Did my roommate wake up at four in the morning and start shaving? Unlikely. That's when I saw the ominous blinking light of my Philips Norelco Bodygroom razor. It turned on by itself! And it wasn't even plugged in! I grabbed it and tried to turn it off but the buttons did nothing. It just kept buzzing, furiously. My roommates woke up from the noise. I panicked and wrapped the razor in a dish towel and then hid it in a kitchen drawer. I realized this might burn the whole apartment building to the ground, so I took it out and stared at it for a full minute. Do I throw it out the window? Stomp on it? Finally, I put the razor back in its cradle and plugged it in--this worked for some reason. And it hasn't worked since. Now when I plug it in it gets REALLY hot so I don't plug it in anymore. This statement applies to this product.<br /><br />Everything functions, but nothing functions well; it gets the job done, but not very efficiently. For instance, the screen-end doesn't save any time over shaving with a good standard multi-blade razor. And, I think it actually hurts a little more than a razor 'cause it plucks a lot.<br /><br />The other end, the \\"clipper\\" end, is also performs poor, especially with the guard on.<br /><br />Neither end does well in the water, which sounded good when reading the reviews, but makes no sense, since you want the hair sticking up, not laying down, stuck to your skin under the adhesive and cohesive forces of water.<br /><br />Wouldn't recommend.
  1405. I ordered this to do one thing - groom. It works. It isn't the end-all-be-all of body grooming tools, but I don't think I could've found a more reliable combo for the money. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who is looking to trim up.
  1406. I'd rather have purchased a corded trimmer, this one gave me more skin irritation than I expected.
  1407. don't buy this thing. it doesn't work well. it hurts your skill some times. i bought another Braun shaver to shave my body
  1408. Shaver works well when it works. But it won't keep a charge. Have went through 2 replacements already and both have the same issue. You follow instructions and charge it, you undock it like it says, and then if you let it sit out a day or two and try to use it, it will no longer have a charge. I actually really like the shaver itself, but the charging issue is really annoying. Update- third replacement was the charm. The charging is as advertised. changing this to 5 stars.

The battery life lasts a little over 20 minutes of use - if that, and the performance is considerably weak after the first 5 minutes of use in a full charge, thus rendering it quite useless after that and until the next recharge.<br /><br />My beard can never be trimmed evenly when I use this machine, nor can I trim it short enough (stubble), which is what I like.<br /><br />The shaver is totally useless... shaves NOTHING!<br /><br />Another negative: you'd have to place the trimmer on the holder in order to charge it - which is especially annoying when you travel extensively as I do, and wish to reduce the amount of items and clutter you carry.<br /><br />On the plus side, the design is futuristic.<br /><br />Conclusion: SAVE YOUR MONEY and don't even think to buy this lousy product.
